subject: Re: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
msgSnippet: ... You should add some info to remind you to write the test (like a @todo javadoc comment or a // TODO: or a fail( not yet implemented )). I like the fail
messageBody:
> If you change the comments, the test can be constructive.
>
> public void testSomeThing()
> {
> // Placeholder for completeness and future tests
> //
> // The tests.other.UsesSomeThingTestSuite and
> // tests.other.SomeThingEqualityTestSuite
> // suites perform exhaustive tests on someThing.
> // When I think of others aspect to test, I'll add them here.
> }

You should add some info to remind you to write the test (like a @todo javadoc comment or a // TODO: or a fail("not yet implemented")).

I like the fail method because it forces you to write the test, or you always have this annoying red bar when you execute your tests.

But if you are writing your tests incrementally (or have all the tests generated by a 3rd party tool), the @todo tag is maybe better. Or you will only see red bars for days (if not weeks) and that's not good for the morale :-)

-Vladimir
